ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This class was an enigma wrapped in an enigma. Why am I studying the case law associated with land use regulations? What's happening?

Marjorie is a bright and engaging instructor, and the content is very interesting. I had the most trouble with how the course was run. It was largely driven by students, and that often made it feel tedious and slow. When Marjorie was driving discussion it was much more engaging, but she preferred to have students lead each class. If there were more structure to each class, I think it would have been more engaging.
Marjorie is great but I just felt like the class could have been more organized.

I had high hopes for this course and was extremely disappointed. Marjorie clearly knows the material and has the potential to teach an instructive and thought-provoking course. However, it quickly became apparent that FES and its student body (including me) do not expect much out of her, and that she in turn expects very little from us. The result was a course in which the students, institution, and instructor failed to hold eachother to anything resembling a respectable standard of academic rigor, and ultimately a waste of time for the students. I feel strongly that courses like this one, which offer students an easy pass in a topic that looks good on a transcript and professionals the chance to 'teach' at Yale, are an example of the very worst elements of our school.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I liked our class discussions about Marjorie's current caseload.
It always put me in a good mood. The instructor is so sweet! And the fact that you didn't know what was going on half the time was really funny.
The individual project was, in my opinion, the best aspect of the course, because it allowed me to apply what we had discussed in class to a topic of my interest.
I thought the term paper was a great opportunity to research a topic that I had specific interest in.

This course provided a great overview of land use law and planning concepts. I really appreciated the balance of breadth and depth and feel that I learned enough to participate in planning and zoning issues in the future.

The granular analysis of various cases was a very valuable process, and I feel much more comfortable reading case law after having taken this course. The final project was a useful space for me to explore a topic of interest.

When engaged outside of class on questions relevant to readings, Marjorie was animated, informative, and useful in clarifying issues that were glossed over during our poorly structured scheduled time.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Some people need to be held more accountable for their case presentations. Sometimes, they explained things inaccurately.

This course seems fundamentally mis-matched for FES. If this were a law school that'd be one thing. But why did we spend all semester reviewing the case law of land use regulations? I think the class was helpful for the one or two joint law students. For the rest of us it was kind of inexplicable.
The course could benefit from more structure - it's run more like a reading group.

The method of course instruction: class instruction was primarily having students read the case briefs they prepared. I did not find this an effective way of learning. Designing these to be more interactive to include discussion questions or prompts could be useful, or having Marjorie summarize the meaning and impact of each case. Class discussion tends to wander off on tangents - I think focusing on key take-home messages from each case or section of the course would be helpful in focusing discussion.

Reading case after case, it was difficult for me to keep the cases organized conceptually. I think a lecture summarizing key points from each unit could have gone a long way. I thought when Marjorie did a good job explaining material, but often it wasn't directly related to what we were reading about.

I think adding in some readings that were more conceptual and broad would have been useful. Varying between reading cases and reading texts from say, a planning journal, would have added a little more diversity to the readings and the flow of the course.

A higher standard for student work would improve the class tremendously. Likewise, the professor *must* put together a more coherent syllabus with clearer learning goals and chances for students to connect course material to relevant topics in other disciplines. The end-of-term paper/presentation, which purports to do just this, is a particular weak point where improvements could be made.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: NA

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This class was a total red herring for me--it had nothing to do with anything I'm interested in. But still intellectually I found it amusing for some reason.

This course complemented my interests in agricultural issues well since it gave me a better understanding of how land use policies were developed and how they play into siting issues. It is also very useful for understanding zoning and development to generally be an informed citizen and participate in guiding future land use decisions.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn more about how land use law fits into environmental planning on the local and regional scale.
I honestly don't remember.
I wanted to understand how land use regulations impact land conservation.
I took this course to further understand the development of land use policies and how they can be altered to encourage smarter growth.
To better understand the legal bases for land use and land management.

I expected to gain a comprehensive introduction to key principles in environmental law. This expectation was not met. Obviously, I came away with some sense of some principles in the field, but no framework with which to judge the scope of the content we covered or to apply it systematically going forward.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Well I guess I gained a basic understanding of how land use law works. Was that the point of the class?
Yes.
Generally yes, but again I think a little more breadth outside of strictly case law would have helped contextualize the cases a bit more.
See above

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Pick the presentation option!

This is not a survey course of land use regulations and laws. It's case law class. Every day you're going to talk about one or two land use cases. It's interesting if you want a law school "light" experience (no cold calling, low stress). But don't expect a comprehensive class about land use. You're going to learn a lot about variances. And you watch a zoning commission hearing on the Madison Beach Hotel three times (that's right, 3 times!). So you're going to become an EXPERT on the Madison Beach Hotel. But honestly this class is hilarious and for some reason I looked forward to it every week even though it seemed random and didn't really seem to fit in. So that's a win! And it's a good introduction to law school if you kind of wondered what it would be like to read a bunch of cases then talk about them in class. Turns out it's kind of hilariously boring.

You will probably get a lot out of the course if you already know a little bit about land use law, but if you don't, the course isn't overly difficult, however it may be difficult to pull out key concepts.
You should take this course if you are at all interested in land use policies -- it's a great foundation and good information to know even if it's not directly linked to your work.
This is a strictly legal course (the land use law is heavy and the planning is light).

Take a course at the law school instead. FES simply should not offer less rigorous alternatives to courses at other schools with the 'environmental' topic tacked on. It is a disservice to the student, who is lead to believe they will be getting something resembling an education, and the school, which I *presume* has an interest encouraging a high standard of scholarship.
Take it!
